articles.headline: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer
articles.snippet: Blood tests are praised as less invasive than traditional procedures, but their usefulness is questioned.
articles.abstract: Blood tests are praised as less invasive than traditional procedures, but their usefulness is questioned.
articles.lead_paragraph: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil — an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.

articles.headline: ‘Flash Boys’ Fuels More Calls for a Tax on Trading
articles.snippet: The publication of a new book on the adverse consequences of high-frequency trading has revived support for a small surcharge on trades to raise revenue for public coffers.
articles.abstract: The publication of a new book on the adverse consequences of high-frequency trading has revived support for a small surcharge on trades to raise revenue for public coffers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that you find a fan club for new taxes, especially among economists and legal experts.

articles.headline: After EMI Debacle, Guy Hands Finds Solace in Gardening
articles.snippet: With the purchase and overhaul of the Garden Centre Group in Britain, Mr. Hands and his private equity firm, Terra Firma, are aiming to get back in the game.
articles.abstract: With the purchase and overhaul of the Garden Centre Group in Britain, Mr. Hands and his private equity firm, Terra Firma, are aiming to get back in the game.
articles.lead_paragraph: Guy Hands tried to make money from the likes of Katy Perry and Coldplay when he bought the music giant EMI in 2007. But he has had much more success selling resin garden animals and bedroom slippers to retirees in garden centers across Britain.

articles.headline: Tech Firms May Find No-Poaching Pacts Costly
articles.snippet: Employees of technology companies have filed a class-action lawsuit that contends that illegal hiring practices among their companies has cost them billions in lost wages.
articles.abstract: Employees of technology companies have filed a class-action lawsuit that contends that illegal hiring practices among their companies has cost them billions in lost wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the talk of the Valley.

articles.headline: Hackers Lurking in Vents and Soda Machines
articles.snippet: Companies are finding that their greatest cybersecurity threats can hide in third-party systems, like networked air-conditioning equipment.
articles.abstract: Companies are finding that their greatest cybersecurity threats can hide in third-party systems, like networked air-conditioning equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — They came in through the Chinese takeout menu.

articles.headline: U.S. Gas Tantalizes Europe, but It’s Not a Quick Fix
articles.snippet: Liquefied natural gas from the United States may hold promise for Europe to reduce its reliance on Russia, but regulatory and market obstacles stand in the way.
articles.abstract: Liquefied natural gas from the United States may hold promise for Europe to reduce its reliance on Russia, but regulatory and market obstacles stand in the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As congressional pressure builds on the Obama administration to quicken gas exports to Europe to reduce its dependence on Russia, it may be tempting to gaze upon a marshy, alligator-infested Louisiana inlet of the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.headline: 2 Tots, a Sailboat and a Storm Over Parenting
articles.snippet: Charlotte and Eric Kaufman became the focus of a debate over parenting after they took their daughters — ages 1 and 3 — on a trip across the South Pacific that ended with a Navy rescue.
articles.abstract: Charlotte and Eric Kaufman became the focus of a debate over parenting after they took their daughters — ages 1 and 3 — on a trip across the South Pacific that ended with a Navy rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As her family began what was supposed to be a monthslong journey in a 36-foot sailboat from Mexico to New Zealand, Charlotte Kaufman wrote openly of her misgivings about taking her two daughters — ages 1 and 3 — to sail the South Pacific, with her husband as captain and herself as the crew.

articles.headline: Wish for Change Animates Voters in India Election
articles.snippet: Narendra Modi, a front-runner for prime minister who campaigned as a technocrat but rose as an ideologue, has won admirers among the disillusioned working and middle classes.
articles.abstract: Narendra Modi, a front-runner for prime minister who campaigned as a technocrat but rose as an ideologue, has won admirers among the disillusioned working and middle classes.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the last several years, as the yearning for a strong leader began to deepen and swell in the Indian electorate, one politician was systematically preparing himself to be the answer to that demand.

articles.headline: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work
articles.snippet: The technology giant will give more assistance to Glass users at businesses, where the wearable device has already found some acceptance.
articles.abstract: The technology giant will give more assistance to Glass users at businesses, where the wearable device has already found some acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At the 500 Club bar in the heart of the Mission district here, patrons are banned from wearing Google Glass. Two miles up the hill at the hospital at the University of California, San Francisco, a lung surgeon wears Glass to assist him as he operates.

articles.headline: Tearful Drama as Pistorius Says He Panicked
articles.snippet: Testifying at his murder trial, the athlete Oscar Pistorius said he and his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, had enjoyed a cozy evening together before it all went wrong.
articles.abstract: Testifying at his murder trial, the athlete Oscar Pistorius said he and his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, had enjoyed a cozy evening together before it all went wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — It was bold, splashy and theatrical, the kind of flourish more often seen in courtroom dramas than in real-life murder trials. In the middle of his emotional and harrowing testimony on Tuesday, the champion sprinter Oscar Pistorius stood up in full view of the packed courtroom, removed his prosthetic legs and demonstrated in a few ungainly steps how very vulnerable and exposed he can be with only his stumps to depend on.

articles.headline: Europe’s Many Jobless See Little Light Yet From Glimmers of a Recovery
articles.snippet: Even as signs of an economic rebound emerge in the euro zone, the human cost of the five-year downturn continues to rise.
articles.abstract: Even as signs of an economic rebound emerge in the euro zone, the human cost of the five-year downturn continues to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — When Kostas Polychronopoulos lost his high-paying marketing position at a telecommunications company at the height of Europe’s financial crisis in 2010, he exhausted himself for more than a year trying to find work.

articles.headline: Comcast Gears Up to Persuade Regulators
articles.snippet: The companies filed documents in support of the plan, which has faced opposition and will be the subject of a Senate hearing this week.
articles.abstract: The companies filed documents in support of the plan, which has faced opposition and will be the subject of a Senate hearing this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Comcast presented regulators on Tuesday with 650 pages of reasons to approve its takeover of Time Warner Cable, saying a merger of the two largest cable television companies would spur rather than inhibit competition by encouraging rivals to improve their cable and high-speed Internet service.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Choice to Oversee Cohen Fund Has Link to It
articles.snippet: The degree of separation between Steven A. Cohen and the consultant selected last week to monitor the operations of the former SAC Capital Advisors is closer than previously known.
articles.abstract: The degree of separation between Steven A. Cohen and the consultant selected last week to monitor the operations of the former SAC Capital Advisors is closer than previously known.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:28 p.m. | The degree of separation between Steven A. Cohen and Bart M. Schwartz, the consultant selected last week to monitor the operations of the former SAC Capital Advisors, is closer than previously known.
